data.title: Allow changing file indentation settings on-the-fly
data.body:
Currently it's impossible to change the indentation settings of the currently open file. At least if there is a way it's very well hidden.

It should be possible to change the indentation of the file I'm working on by simply clicking on the current indentation setting displayed in the status bar:

![atom-indent](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1457035/5297143/deaee6b8-7ba3-11e4-80e4-2b3f6d664e4c.png)

This should open some kind of dialog (or some other mechanism) that allows me to change the indentation setting for the currently open file.

This is especially important if the [auto-detect-indentation](https://github.com/jtokoph/auto-detect-indentation) package is installed, because it currently makes it impossible to change the indentation setting for the open file.

data.title: Weird issue with atom-space-pen-views installation in Atom v0.152
data.body:
I recently moved my [project-palette-finder package](https://github.com/abe33/atom-project-palette-finder) on `atom-space-pen-views` as suggested in the deprecation messages. 

So I released v2.4.0 and didn't noticed any issues in the updated version on my various computers. (I always link my package with `--dev` option in order to test the released version when running `atom`) 

However, [bug reports](https://github.com/abe33/atom-project-palette-finder/issues/16#issuecomment-65506476) started to popup. 
With some trial and errors I could figure that [despite having `atom-space-pen-views` correctly installed](https://github.com/abe33/atom-project-palette-finder/issues/16#issuecomment-65448631), in their context, running `require 'atom-space-pen-views'` returns an object without the `View` class (and probably many other, I didn't tried to log the keys of the returned object). 

I put [some warning in my code](https://github.com/abe33/atom-project-palette-finder/blob/master/lib/project-palette-color-view.coffee#L4-L6) to [confirm that](https://github.com/abe33/atom-project-palette-finder/issues/16#issuecomment-65506476), and as you can see in the logs, the test on `View` existence failed and the warning was triggered (the other errors are irrelevant for that specific issue).

FWIW I asked @jasesmith to provide me with the [`package.json` of the package once installed](https://gist.github.com/jasesmith/3cf91469b2bb1c4282cb) and, compared to [mine](https://gist.github.com/abe33/00dea48ae6f3d8a25cd7), I can't find a significant difference. 
The thing that puzzles me is that `atom-space-pen-views` is the only dependencies that is not referenced in the `__atomModuleCache` object (while `space-pen` is) but as it works on my computer I doubt it's the reason for these errors.

Am I missing something or is this a bug?

data.title: Crash on right click after opening folder Linux
data.body:
Application crashes with the following output after I right click having opened a folder, but not opened any files (so the untitled file is the only file showing). 

Running atom 0.152.0 on Debian jessie/sid -- partially on testing, partially on stable -- using i3 for window management (kdm underlying I believe). I am aware this is a bit of a funky setup. The error also occurs in safe mode.

To confirm, steps to reproduce:
1. Run atom (from command line to see error output)
2. File -> Open Folder...
3. Choose a folder (at first I was using a network drive, but no difference with local FS)
4. Right click in empty file editing window
Application crashes.

Error output on console is as follows:

```
[9107:1203/111941:ERROR:browser_main_loop.cc(162)] Running without the SUID sandbox! See https://code.google.com/p/chromium/wiki/LinuxSUIDSandboxDevelopment for more information on developing with the sandbox on.
App load time: 141ms
[9141:1203/111942:INFO:renderer_main.cc(204)] Renderer process started
[9107:1203/111943:INFO:CONSOLE(64)] "Window load time: 1270ms", source: file:///usr/share/atom/resources/app/static/index.js (64)
The program 'atom' received an X Window System error.
This probably reflects a bug in the program.                                                                                                                                            
The error was 'BadWindow (invalid Window parameter)'.                                                                                                                                   
  (Details: serial 4532 error_code 3 request_code 3 minor_code 0)                                                                                                                       
  (Note to programmers: normally, X errors are reported asynchronously;                                                                                                                 
   that is, you will receive the error a while after causing it.                                                                                                                        
   To debug your program, run it with the --sync command line                                                                                                                           
   option to change this behavior. You can then get a meaningful                                                                                                                        
   backtrace from your debugger if you break on the gdk_x_error() function.)  
```

- **Misc**

data.title: cmd-down does not create newlines
data.body:
If you use `cmd-down` to move a line of code downwards it does not create newlines. This means you can't use `cmd-down` like this:

before

```
line1
line2
--> file ends here <--
```

after

```
line2

line1
--> file ends here <--
```

This is useful if you want to split existing code into several methods at the end of a file.

data.title: Debain Package Updating
data.body:
It's really awesome that you now host a official Debian package for atom, however, there is one area for improvement, updating. Currently, you have to check the website for updates and then go to the atom website to download the new Debian package. This is ignoring one of the most useful parts of the debian packaging system, the updater. On Debian, packages are updated (almost) automatically via PPA's (Personal Package Archives) which are hosted for free by Ubuntu at launchpad.net or packages repositories, which you need to host yourself. 

A PPA is probably the easiest solution. All you would have to do is upload the Debian package to launchapd.net whenever you upload it to atom's website.

Google Chrome also does this nifty thing that is really useful and I think atom should implement as well. You download the Debian package from the Google Chrome website, and the Debian installer automatically adds the package repository to the users system for updates in the future.

If you have any more questions or need help setting this up I'm happy to help. 

It's free, requires almost no work on your part to set up and maintain, and improves the updating experience on Linux by a lot. Thanks! :smile:

data.title: Support adding multiple classes to a decoration
data.body:
While migrating the `git-diff` package to use non-deprecated APIs, I wanted to add two classes to the decoration, one for the type (added, removed, modified) and one for whether to show the file icon.

It fails with this error if the `class` key is a string with spaces:

```
Error: Failed to execute 'add' on 'DOMTokenList': The token provided ('git-line-modified git-file-icon') contains HTML space characters, which are not valid in tokens.
  at Error (native)
  at [object Object].module.exports.React.createClass.updateLineNumberNode
```

data.title: Indention still doesn't work entirely as expected
data.body:
It got much better, but consider the following HTML-Scenario: ``` html
Test
``` When I copy the `` and paste it (2 empty spaces before), Sublime3 gives me (the expected result): ``` html
Test Test
``` in Atom (OSX, 0.152) it becomes: ``` html
Test Test
``` Auto-Indent is turned on for `language html`. Are there any plans to enhance this for 1.0?

data.title: Atom Cursor causes high CPU load (20% x 2 processors.)
data.body:
The way atom does cursors causes a high CPU load when debugging anything inside of atom because it is constantly causing chrome inspector to update which is apparently very expensive.  It would be nice if the cursor would also pause when the inspector is in focus, or for there to even be an option to simply disable the blink entirely since it has many performance problems (actually, if the cursor weren't blinking there would be no CPU usage in general with Atom on my Linux system.)

There is probably a ticket for the latter but the former is an issue of it's own I think (I searched.)

data.title: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'tokenAtBufferColumn' of undefined
data.body:
Hi, I am getting error Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'tokenAtBufferColumn' of undefined.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open Atom with atom --safe.
2. Create new lines.
3. Select them.
4. Use command Editor: Split Selections Into lines.
5. Write something.
6. Press escape to cancel multi selection.
7. Run Core:Undo.
8. Run Core:Undo for second time.

Gif with example:

![](https://virtual-host-discourse.global.ssl.fastly.net/uploads/github_atom/25437/cc83b11b0d27552d.gif)

[Whole stack trace.](https://gist.github.com/Trudko/cab20d6a4f6299bd44e9)

I have tried this on Windows 7 Pro and Ubuntu 14.04 both running Atom 0.152. I might try this on Windows 8 if this helps

Issue seems similiar to https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/3187.

data.title: Undo grouping is too eager
data.body:
Undo grouping seems to group any editor changes no matter what kind of change it was, which results in confusing/unexpected behaviour.
1. Create a new file
2. Paste some text into it
3. Immediately begin typing
4. Undo

Atom will group both the pasting and the typing, so the undo removes everything. Ideally it should only remove the typing, with the paste being a separate undo. ST2 has this behaviour and its much nicer. I'll often start typing after pasting some code, and want to undo something I just typed. It's infuriating when the whole lot disappears!

The same problem happens for many editor commands such as `editor:auto-indent`. Perform an auto indent, then begin typing (or run another command). Undo will revert both.

My suggestion is that Atom should only group sequences of identical commands. Disparate commands should never be grouped.

Are there cases where grouping disparate commands makes more sense than keeping them separate?

data.title: New packages not installing Mac
data.body:
Hi
I don't know if your aware but new packages, that is packages not already installed, won't install if Xcode has been updated and not used. The reason is the Xcode terms have to be agreed to in the welcome window. This may also be an issue with other apps that use npm and git for users that have Xcode installed but don't use it much. It took me a while to resolve this issue so it may be worth mentioning it on the Atom site.
Billy Chick

data.title: Out of disk space causes Atom to zero out a file?
data.body:
This is on OSX 10.10.1 with Atom 0.15.0

I had an issue today where I ran out of disk space, and Atom seemed to wipe out a previously saved file.

As in, this file had already been saved, I opened it in Atom, saved, then I quit Atom. Then when I restarted Atom, the file was empty.

I checked with `ls`, the file was empty and 0 bytes.

I do understand that running out of disk space is certainly not a normal condition, but is there any explanation that would explain how Atom would completely wipe out the contents of the file as a result?

data.title: Add subword cursors - take 2
data.body:
Fixes #1982 and an alternative to #3961. Also, hopefully can used with atom/vim-mode#377.

I haven't added keymaps yet. But maybe:

``` cson
'.platform-linux .editor, .platform-win32 .editor':
  'alt-left': 'editor:move-to-previous-subword-boundary'
  'alt-right': 'editor:move-to-next-subword-boundary'
  'alt-shift-left': 'editor:select-to-previous-subword-boundary'
  'alt-shift-right': 'editor:select-to-next-subword-boundary'
  'alt-backspace': 'editor:delete-to-beginning-of-subword'
  'alt-k': 'editor:delete-to-end-of-subword'

'.platform-darwin .editor':
  'ctrl-alt-left': 'editor:move-to-previous-subword-boundary'
  'ctrl-alt-right': 'editor:move-to-next-subword-boundary'
  'ctrl-alt-shift-left': 'editor:select-to-previous-subword-boundary'
  'ctrl-alt-shift-right': 'editor:select-to-next-subword-boundary'
  'ctrl-alt-backspace': 'editor:delete-to-beginning-of-subword'
  'ctrl-alt-k': 'editor:delete-to-end-of-subword'
```

Sorry for changing most lines in text-editor-spec.coffee. I had to add a separate fixtures file for better tests. If there is a better way than wrapping everything in a describe block, than let me know. I could make a separate file, but that's probably not what you want.

Also, I can't figure out how to go left on the first line when there is only white space, see cursor.moveToSubwordBoundary(), /^[\t ]*$/ isn't working.

data.title: Menu reads "Downloading update ..." even when it is only checking for an update
data.body:
The menu text reads "Download update ..." while checking for an update even in cases where there is no update.

Perhaps it should read "Checking for updates ..." and only change to "Downloading update ..." if an update is available.
